2.62.text: And one of the leading ways people nowadays deal with them, is meditation.

7.12.text: Sessions where you quieten thoughts, empty the mind,

10.88.text: and focus on just a few things outside of you

13.96.text: like, the rustle of leaves, or the flow of water.

18.38.text: But, at the School of Life, we want to put forward an alternative,

24.82.text: We've devised a technique, based not on Eastern thought,

28.60.text: but on ideas that come down to us from the Western philosophical tradition.

37.64.text: The basic premise is that a lot of the trouble in our minds,

41.22.text: comes from thoughts that haven't been untangled, examined, and properly confronted.

47.00.text: And that because life moves so fast, we accumulate a lot of un-thought thoughts

55.56.text: is chiefly the revenge of thoughts we havent had in the day.

60.18.text: Muddled, unfocused thoughts generate a static of anxious electricity,

65.04.text: or else give rise to clouds of nonspecific gloom.

69.28.text: If we've been out of touch with our thoughts for too long,

71.98.text: we can get snappy or suddenly enraged.

75.10.text: This, is what philosophical meditation is designed to help us with.

79.56.text: It's a tool for systematically clearing up our minds,

83.10.text: and making sense of our disavowed feelings and ideas.

87.32.text: The first priority, is to set aside a bit of time.

90.44.text: Idealy some twenty minutes at least once every few days.

94.22.text: You should sit, probably in bed, early in the morning,

96.94.text: or late in the evening, with a pad of paper,

99.70.text: and ancher your investigation of yourself around 3 large questions.

105.50.text: Firstly: "What am I currently anxious about?"

109.98.text: Secondly: "What am I upset about, and with whom?"

114.30.text: And thirdly: "What am I currently excited and ambitious about?"

120.18.text: At first, when asked to respond to question like these

123.78.text: the mind tends to be inarticulate and a bit scared.

127.54.text: Generally, something comes to mind, but often you can't quite tell what it is yet.

132.24.text: It might, just for now, be a word, or a mental image, or a place, or a persons name.

139.36.text: Grab the ideas when they're there without thinking too much, write everything down,

143.70.text: however minor, and don't worry too much about it's ultimate sense.

148.42.text: Philosophical meditation can be compared to cleaning out a large, clogged-up cupboard.

153.32.text: You have to take everything out and pile it up on the bed first

156.60.text: before starting to sort it out.

159.10.text: So, to kick off, under: "What am I anxious about?"

162.12.text: You might accumulate a list of concerns you haven't looked at head on,

165.62.text: but have glimpsed in the course of the day.

168.36.text: It'll be nonsense to anyone else,

170.38.text: and perhaps almost to yourself too, but keep going.

173.94.text: With all the thoughts taken out, then past and through the sieve of a set of questions.

178.90.text: Ask: "What is this anxiety really about?"

182.30.text: Tell the story of the coming anxious period or challenge in great, almost tedious detail.

189.06.text: Then, confront head on everything that could go wrong

192.40.text: with the worrying situation or idea.

195.92.text: Now tease out how you might still be OK, even if the worst happened.

200.62.text: Don't cheer yourself up with false optimism.

203.16.text: Make yourself at home with the darkest possibilities.

206.58.text: Realize that almost everything is ultimately rather survivable.

211.82.text: Then, it's time to move on to the second part of the philosophical meditation;

216.18.text: the bit where you ask the second big question:

218.92.text: "Who am I upset with and why?"

222.10.text: The theory here, is that we often don't allow ourselves

224.90.text: to analyze the hurts that we receive from other people

228.18.text: because we're humiliatingly vulnerable and pretend we're not.

232.72.text: Yet we pay for this false stoicism dearly.

235.76.text: For undigested hurts generate bitterness, confusion,

241.66.text: We might go cold on our partners, with whom we're unknowingly furious.

246.86.text: So, empty the cupboard of the mind of all its multiple hurts.

251.70.text: Take all you've written, and pass it through the following set of questions:

257.40.text: Retell yourself all of the upsetting incidents you've faced,

260.88.text: in great detail, as if you were telling them to an extremely kind, interested

269.02.text: "How might a nice person have end up doing what this person did to you?"

275.56.text: What other explanations could there be for the hurt they have caused?

280.24.text: Lastly, if this would happen to a friend, how would you advise them?

285.22.text: Next, it's time to take out of the cupboard of the mind all the thoughts

288.30.text: that relate to ambition, and excitement.

291.54.text: This needs a range of positive emotions,

293.74.text: tremors of interest, tentative enthusiasm to lights and so on

298.04.text: that are hovering on the edges of consciousness.

301.20.text: Ask: "What recently made you feel excited, envious or desiring?"

306.98.text: There's then an another set of questions to sieve these feelings through.

310.76.text: Describe your excitements as if to a sympathetic, interested friend.

315.74.text: You need to change your life in certain ways,

317.70.text: so, what would it be, to change your life in the light of this?

322.70.text: This exciting thing holds clue to whats missing in your life, what might be missing?

327.78.text: If this thing could talk, what might it tell you?

331.48.text: If this thing could try to change your life, what changes might it advise?

336.22.text: If other parts of your life were more like this, what might they be like?

340.80.text: Answering all these questions starts the vital work

343.94.text: of decoding the scrambled thoughts, that normally clog up our minds.

348.84.text: The longer we've gone without doing one of these mental audits,

352.32.text: the more there will be to go through.

354.82.text: Philosophical meditation doesn't magically solve problems,

358.44.text: but it huuugely helps us, by creating an occasion

361.52.text: where we can identify our thoughts, and get them in some kind of order.

366.44.text: Fears, resentments, and hopes become easier to name.

369.84.text: We get less scared of the contents of our own minds

372.66.text: we grow calmer, less bitter and clearer about our diection in life.

376.78.text: We start, at last on the journey to knowing ourselves properly.
